title: How did Jonathan Harker escape Dracula castle in Bram's Stoker Dracula? - Quora

response.answer_text: Wondering if you’re asking about the Coppola film, which I dislike intensely and which may have had a different escape — can’t remember. In the novel, Harker has seen the Count climbing almost insect-like on the walls of the castle and down a steep cliff. He also notices that the Count is wearing his, Harker’s, clothes, probably to build up evidence that Harker himself has left the castle. Harker made several failed attempts to post letters, or give letters to the local peasants, or enlist their help in some way. The Count has forced Harker to write three letters to his employer in London, saying all is well. The last letter says Harker has set out for home. This date is, Harker realizes, the date that the Count will kill him. So in the daylight hours left to him, Harker sets out for the Count’s lair, which he had found before. He finds the Count paralyzed but more robust from a recent feed, and strikes him a glancing blow with a shovel. Then Harker prepares to make the hazardous climb to freedom, and Stoker leaves us wondering whether he makes it, until a later chapter.

He crawled down the walls of the castle, as one would climb up or down the straight face of a mountain. There were indentations between the stones on the exterior walls of the castle, and he was able to crawl down the walls after Count Dracula left for England. He left the castle, and was found ill by some Transylvanian nuns, who nursed him back to health.
